bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Frederick F. Russell, March 8, 1924

div1.p: Connor reports on the yellow fever work in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Frederick F. Russell, March 8, 1924
div1.opener:
Copy
Veracruz, Ver.
March 8, 1924
International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York, N.Y.
Sir: Attention Dr. F. F. Russell
div1.p:
The prospects for transportation to Merida are not bright for
the very near future. It appears that the plans of the Federal Government
is to clear the Isthmus before beginning a campaign against the rebels in
Yucatan, this may take months to accomplish.

My work in Veracruz will be concluded within the next few days
when I plan to return to Tampico and will visit if possible the Huastecas
and Tuxpam after which I will be ready to return to the States.

While in Veracruz I am visiting the Hospitals, Sanatoriums,
Military Dispensaries and conferring with as many of the practicing physi-
cians as can be reached and more especially with Drs. Iglesias and Loyo,
both of whom are connected with the military and civil hospitals, and they
assure me that there has not been any cases suspicious of yellow fever in-
fection. I have carefully studied the mortality records and do not find
in them any suggestion of yellow fever.

The military are interested in this infection and have been
specially directed to be on the lookout for it. They all report in the
negative.

Doctor Gimbler, representative for the U.S.P.H. Service in this
Port, has made an independent investigation and is reporting to his Bureau
that he cannot find any trace of yellow fever here. From instructions
received by Doctor Gimbler it appears that the quarantine or close season
between Mexican and United States ports will start on April 1st next and
that ships will be fumigated before leaving here or on arrival at a U.S.
port. No passenger quarantine is contemplated.

The Departamento has detailed Doctor Juan Graham Casasus to
Veracruz and instructed him to inaugurate an anti-mosquito service in this
city. The work actually started on March 1st and will continue as long
as funds are available for this class of work.

You will be interested to know that Doctor Alfredo Iglesias has
been continued by the Departamento as Bacteriologist for this zone. The
cultures of leptospira icteroides which the doctor carried with him from
New York are available for use by the Departamento.
With very good wishes, I am
